[[Asteroid color indices|U–B]] = 0.380 | abs_magnitude = {{val|11.16|0.34}}{{·}}11.36{{·}}11.43 }} '''1957 Angara''', provisional designation {{mp|1970 GF}}, is a stony Eoan [[asteroid]] from the outer regions of the [[asteroid belt]], approximately 18 kilometers in diameter. It was discovered on 1 April 1970, by Soviet astronomer [[Lyudmila Chernykh]] at the [[Crimean Astrophysical Observatory]] in Nauchnyj, and named after the Siberian [[Angara River]]. == Classification and orbit == ''Angara'' is a member of the [[Eos family]], well known for mostly being of a [[S-type asteroid|silicaceous]] composition. It orbits the Sun in the [[Kirkwood gap|outer]] main-belt at a distance of 2.8–3.2 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 5 years and 3 months (1,906 days). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.06 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 11[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. A first [[precovery]] was taken at [[Goethe Link Observatory]] in 1956, extending the body's [[observation arc]] by 14 years prior to its official discovery observation at Nauchnyj. == Physical characteristics == In December 1983, a rotational [[lightcurve]] of ''Angara'' was obtained from photometric observations by American astronomer [[Richard Binzel]] . Lightcurve analysis gave a well-define [[rotation period]] of 3.67 hours with a brightness amplitude of 0.52 [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]], indicative of a non-spheroidal shape ({{small|[[LCDB quality code|U=3]]}}). Binzel also classified the body as a stony [[S-type asteroid]]. According to the surveys carried out by the Japanese [[Akari (satellite)|Akari]] satellite and NASA's [[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer]] with its subsequent [[NEOWISE]] mission, ''Angara'' measures between 17.907 and 30.41 kilometers in diameter and its surface has an [[astronomical albedo|albedo]] between 0.055 and 0.1438. The ''Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link'' assumes a standard albedo for stony Eoan asteroids of 0.14 – taken from the family's largest member and namesake, [[221 Eos]] – and derives a diameter of 18.38 kilometers with an [[absolute magnitude]] of 11.43. == Naming == This [[minor planet]] was named for the over 1000-mile long Siberian [[Angara River]] that drains [[Lake Baikal]]. The approved naming citation was published by the [[Minor Planet Center]] before November 1977 ({{small|[[Minor Planet Circulars|M.P.C.]] 4190}}). == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |type = 2017-06-02 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: 1957 Angara (1970 GF) |url = http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2001957 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 2 July 2017}} {{cite book |title = Dictionary of Minor Planet Names – (1957) Angara |last = Schmadel | first = Lutz D. |publisher = [[Springer Berlin Heidelberg]] |page = 157 |date = 2007 |url = https://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-3-540-29925-7_1958 |isbn = 978-3-540-00238-3 |accessdate = 4 April 2017}} {{cite web |title = 1957 Angara (1970 GF) |work = Minor Planet Center |url = http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=1957 |accessdate = 4 April 2017}} {{cite web |title = MPC/MPO/MPS Archive |work = Minor Planet Center |url = http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/ECS/MPCArchive/MPCArchive_TBL.html |accessdate = 4 April 2017}} {{cite journal |display-authors = 6 |first1 = Joseph R. |last1 = Masiero |first2 = A. {{Infobox military unit | unit_name = 3rd Field Artillery Regiment, Royal Canadian Artillery "The Loyal Company" | image = | caption = The badge of the Royal Regiment of Canadian Artillery. | dates = 04 May 1869-present | country = [[Canada]] | branch = Army | type = Field Artillery | size = One Regiment | garrison = Saint John, New Brunswick | command_structure = [[Royal Regiment of Canadian Artillery]] | ceremonial_chief = | ceremonial_chief_label = | colonel_of_the_regiment = | motto = ''Ubique. Quo fas et gloria ducunt.'' (Everywhere. Whither right and glory lead) | identification_symbol = | identification_symbol_label = | nickname = The Loyal Company | battles = | march = Quick: British Grenadiers }}
The '''3rd Field Artillery Regiment, RCA''' is a [[Canadian Army]] Reserve [[artillery]] regiment based in [[Saint John, New Brunswick]]. It is part of the [[5th Canadian Division]]'s [[37 Canadian Brigade Group]].
The Loyal Company of Artillery of the City of Saint John was formed on May 4, 1793 after passed its first ''Militia Act'' in 1792 in response to the outbreak of the French Revolutionary Wars. Since that historic founding The Loyal Company of Artillery formed the core of a body of militia artillery that has existed in the province right up to the present day in the form of 3rd Field Artillery Regiment, Royal Canadian Artillery. For much of the 20th century the Regiment proudly carried "The Loyal Company" designation as part of its title, perpetuating the connection to Canada's oldest artillery unit.The Loyal Company was the first of several militia artillery companies, renamed batteriesin the later nineteenth century, formed in for the defence of the colony's mainport and border towns from outside threat.
'''War of 1812'''
The threat of war with the United States proved real enough in 1812 that New Brunswick militia artillery detachments were activated as part of the 1st and 2nd Battalions of the to man newly built shore batteries in overlooking the Passamaquoddy Bay and the coast of disputed territory in what is now the State of. Throughout the War of 1812 other detachments of militia artillerymen built and manned defences alongside British regular gunners around .
'''The New Brunswick Regiment of Artillery'''
Saint John's importance as the key all-season port of entry into British North America and then meant that the city garrison was always armed and provisioned for defense from the sea. Artillery was central to that defense, making the garrison a logical focal point for the training and equipping of 's militia artillery from across the province. In 1838 militia artillery companies throughout the province were unified as the New Brunswick Regiment of Artillery. The core and headquarters of this force was the original Loyal Company and the gun batteries defending the harbour. Indeed, the NB Regiment of Artillery was formed to man those vital defenses when the British regular artillery garrison marched west in response to the '''Rebellions of 1837 and 1838''' in Upper and . That same year, the Regiment was called on to dispatch a troop of artillery to during the border dispute known as the '''War of 1838-39'''. Despite funding shortages, the Regiment continued to maintain a high standard of readiness and artillery skill-at-arms largely due to a continuation of the same volunteer spirit that inspired the Loyal Company of Artillery. That readiness was apparent in 1866 during '''the Fenian Raids''' when the Regiment manned the gun batteries around and along the border at . A decade later, they once again stood guard at the nation's coastal defenses during the '''1878 war scare with .''' They also came to the aid of the civil powers during the Saint John Great Fire of 1877 using their specialist skills in handling high explosives to blow down walls for a fire break. These dramatic highlights as well as more routine mustering for summer training camps and ceremonial occasions established the Regiment of Artillery as a proud and well-known element of 's defence forces. The province of New Brunswick and the City of Saint John recognized the many contributions of this regiment when it celebrated the founding of the Loyal Company with a grand centennial ball in May 1893.
'''20th Century Defending at Home and Abroad'''
In 1895, as part of a wave of Canadian defense modernization and national organization, the unit was first identified with its modern numerical designation and named the 3rd (New Brunswick) Regiment of Canadian Garrison Artillery. It counted among its members Lieutenant-Colonel C.W. Drury, considered to be the father of 's modern artillery. Drury commanded The Canadian Brigade of Artillery during the '''South African War,''' which included a troop of gunners from the Regiment's 89th Battery in Woodstock . LCol Drury was himself the son of LCol Richard Hayne, the Regiment's first commanding officer at the time of formation in 1838. So began the new 20th century reputation for excellence not only for manning defenses at home but also for raising well-trained artillerymen for overseas service.
'''The Great War, 1914-1918'''
The day after war broke out in August 1914 the Regiment barged its 4.7inch heavy guns to protect the mouth of the Saint John harbour . For the duration of the war, the Regiment stood on guard against the very real threat of German cruisers and submarines on Canada's east coast. The unit's heavy guns and experienced artillerymen also served to train thousands of volunteers from New Brunswick and eastern Canada for service in the Canadian Corps Heavy Artillery formed in 1916 in . The Regiment also contributed personnel to the 2nd Divisional Ammunition Column and the 1st Canadian Heavy Battery, among them future commanding officers LCol "Harry" Harrison and Major Cyrus Inches.
'''The Guns of Vimy, Passchendaele and the 100 Days'''
In 1916 volunteers from the Regiment travelled overseas as 4th and 6th Canadian Siege Batteries, firing their first shots in anger during the Battle of the Somme of the . There they perfected new techniques of long range counter-battery bombardment. The Canadian Corps Heavy Artillery, including 4th and 6th Siege Batteries gathered together for the first time with the whole of the Canadian Corps in the spring of 1917. That April they fired what has gone down in history as one of the most successful counter-battery bombardments in history, neutralizing over 80 percent of the German artillery and paving the way for Canadian infantrymen to take Vimy Ridge. From Vimy, 4th and 6th Canadian Siege Batteries were joined in 1918 by 3rd Brigade, Canadian Garrison Artillery, made up mostly of New Brunswick and Maritime gunners trained in Saint John. The Regiment became the core of the Canadian Corps Heavy Artillery during the Great War. New Brunswick heavy gunners supported the Corps in the difficult fighting for the final 100 Days Campaign. Our batteries played an especially important role in the dramatic Canadian victory at the Canal du Nord and Cambrai in September 1918. At the end of the Great War, surviving veterans came home to what became known as 3rd (New Brunswick) Coast Brigade, Royal Canadian Artillery, (The Loyal Company of Artillery). Many veterans stayed active in the interwar militia, keeping alive the specialized skill set of long range artillery.
'''The Second World War, 1939-1945'''
In 1939 3rd (New Brunswick) Coast Brigade, RCA, (The Loyal Company of Artillery) mobilized to prepare and man new heavy coastal gun batteries constructed around Saint John. The threat of German surface raiders and submarines was even greater in the Second World War than in the first, requiring much of the Regiment's attention. However, the requirements for trained artillerymen for overseas service led to the despatch of four batteries from the regiment. 89th Battery from Woodstock mustered as field artillery while 90th and 104th Batteries from Fredericton assembled as anti-tank units. All three were despatched to Italy, taking part in the Canadian victory at the '''Hitler Line''' that opened the '''liberation of Rome .''' 105th from Saint John also went overseas as an anti-tank unit, landing in '''Normandy''' and taking part in the climactic '''Battle of the Falaise Gap''' and '''The Battle of the Scheldt .'''
'''1945-2012'''
The close of the Second World War ended direct threats to Canada's east coast by sea. The new threat to Canadian security in the early Cold War era came from Soviet bombers carrying nuclear weapons. In response the Regiment was re-organized as a medium anti-aircraft unit. The threat of aircraft gave way to ballistic missiles, and the Canadian Army once again organized for forward conventional defence in Europe as a leading member of the Treaty Organization. In that context, in 1962 the Regiment evolved into its present role as the 3rd Field Artillery Regiment (The Loyal Company), Royal Canadian Artillery. Since then the Regiment has continued in its same function since the Loyal Company was formed in 1793; to maintain a reserve force of trained artillerymen to defend at home and abroad. In recent decades, the most visible form of that mission has been to provide gunners and officers to augment regular force Royal Canadian Artillery batteries deployed for overseas service on peace-keeping, peace-enforcement and stability operations. In the last four decades hundreds of 3rd Field Artillery Regiment gunners have served in, '''Cyprus''' the '''Golan Heights''', the Former '''Yugoslavia''', '''Somolia''', and most recently'''. the South Sudan''' A mission of particular pride was in support of the Canadian Forces's efforts in '''Afghanistan''', where the requirement for Canadian soldiers with artillery and observer skills once again became paramount.The Loyal Company title was officially shorn as the Regiment's post-nominal title on 20 November 1975, apparently as part of the wider policy of separating the unified Canadian Forces from traditions and customs associated with . Nevertheless, the unit continues to perpetuate the link its 1793 foundation. After a loud appeal the Canadian Government restored the Loyal Company to the regiment's official name in 2012. Members of this regiment stand ready by their guns at your service. *
==Perpetuations==

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} Since the early Islamic states of the eighth and ninth centuries, Islamic law (known in [[Arabic]] as [[sharia]]) always existed alongside other [[normative]] systems.{{cite book|last=Otto|first=Jan Michiel|title=Sharia Incorporated: A Comparative Overview of the Legal Systems of Twelve Muslim Countries in Past and Present|year=2009|publisher=Leiden University Press|location=Leiden|isbn=978-9087280574|pages=615–16|url=http://dare.uva.nl/document/221087|access-date=13 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105224404/http://dare.uva.nl/document/221087#|archive-date=5 November 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Within sharia, some crimes are known as ''[[hudud]]'', for which there are specific penalties specified by Islam. For example, according to some interpretations, [[adultery]] is punished by stoning, [[fornication]] and the consumption of alcohol by lashing, and theft by the amputation of limbs. Many predominately Muslim countries have not adopted ''[[hudud]]'' penalties in their criminal justice systems. [[Ali Mazrui]] stated that "most Muslim countries do not use traditional classical Islamic punishments". {{cite book|last1=Pate|first1=Matthew|last2=Gould|first2=Laurie A.|title=Corporal Punishment Around the World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Uf-1r3SVVrYC&pg=PA51|accessdate=1 April 2013|date=31 August 2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0313391316|page=51}} The harshest penalties are enforced with varying levels of consistency,{{cite web|title=The Emergence of Sharia Law|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/africa/nigeria/sharia_law.html|publisher=Online NewsHour|accessdate=20 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308024100/http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/africa/nigeria/sharia_law.html#|archive-date=8 March 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} and although most Muslim-majority countries adopt various aspects of sharia, some countries may only adopt a few aspects, whereas others apply the entire sharia code.{{cite web|title=I have a right to|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/people/features/ihavearightto/four_b/casestudy_art07.shtml|publisher=BBC World Service|accessdate=24 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111012051559/http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/people/features/ihavearightto/four_b/casestudy_art07.shtml#|archive-date=12 October 2011|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The use of [[flagellation|flogging]] is more common compared to punishments like amputations. The adoption and demand for sharia in the legal system of nations with significant Muslim-minorities is an active topic of international debate.{{cite news|last1=Brooks-Pollock|first1=Tom|title=The countries where a majority of Muslims want to live under Sharia law|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/the-countries-where-a-majority-of-muslims-want-to-live-under-sharia-law-a6773666.html|accessdate=10 October 2017|work=The Independent|date=15 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011073116/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/the-countries-where-a-majority-of-muslims-want-to-live-under-sharia-law-a6773666.html#|archive-date=11 October 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Introducing sharia as the [[law of the land]] in Muslim-majority nations has been described as "a longstanding goal for Islamist movements",Lapidus, Ira (1996), ''The Cambridge Illustrated History of the Islamic World edited by Francis Robinson'', Cambridge University Press, pp. 293–98. "The reintroduction of Sharia is a longstanding goal for Islamist movements in Muslim countries". and attempts to introduce or expand sharia have been accompanied by controversy,Hamann, Katie (29 December 2009). [http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/religion/Acehs-Sharia-Law-Still-Controversial-in-Indonesia-80257482.html "Aceh's Sharia Law Still Controversial in Indonesia"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100411072718/http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/religion/Acehs-Sharia-Law-Still-Controversial-in-Indonesia-80257482.html# |date=11 April 2010 }}. [[Voice of America]]. Retrieved 19 September 2011. * Iijima, Masako (13 January 2010). [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 18 September 2011. * [http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2010/02/08/aceh-sharia-police-loved-and-hated.html "Aceh Sharia Police Loved and Hated"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171017002416/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2010/02/08/aceh-sharia-police-loved-and-hated.html# |date=17 October 2017 }}. Most countries of the world do not recognize sharia; however, some that do recognize sharia use it as the basis for divorce, inheritance and other personal affairs of their Islamic population.{{cite book|last=Otto|first=Jan Michiel|title=Sharia and National Law in Muslim Countries|publisher=Amsterdam University Press|isbn=978-9087280482}} And in countries where Islam is the predominant religion, sharia is fully instituted, including laws governing punishment for sin against Allah and Islam – not just divorce, inheritance and personal affairs.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} ==Definition and scope== [[Sharia]] law in this article means the [[moral code]] and [[religious law]] of Islam. It includes criminal, civil, personal, economic and all aspects of law as revealed in Quran and Hadiths; in its strictest and most historically coherent definition, sharia is considered the infallible law of [[Allah]].Coulson, N. J. (2011), ''A history of Islamic law'', Aldine, {{ISBN|978-1412818551}} The primary sources of sharia are the precepts set forth in the [[Quranic]] verses ([[ayah]]s), and the example set by the Islamic prophet [[Muhammad]] in the [[Sunnah]].Esposito, John (2001), ''Women in Muslim family law'', Syracuse University Press, {{ISBN|978-0815629085}} The scope of sharia includes Islamic law as interpreted by Islamic judges ([[qadis]]) with varying responsibilities for the religious leaders. For questions not directly addressed in the [[primary sources]], sharia includes consensus of the religious scholars (''[[ulama]]'') thought to embody the consensus of the Muslim Community (''[[ijma]]''). ==Classification== The legal systems of Muslim countries may be grouped as: mixed systems, classical sharia systems, and secular systems.{{cite book|last=Otto|first=Jan Michiel|title=Sharia and National Law in Muslim Countries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f9XaP-ufhPQC&pg=PA8|accessdate=11 March 2013|date=30 August 2008|publisher=Amsterdam University Press|isbn=978-9087280482|pages=635–36}} ===Classical sharia systems=== Classical sharia systems are those where sharia plays a dominant role and is present in most areas of a nation's legal system. Iran, Saudi Arabia and Sudan are examples of classical sharia systems. ===Secular systems=== Secular systems are those where sharia plays no role in the nation's legal system. Turkey is an example of a Muslim-majority nation with a secular system. ===Mixed systems=== Mixed systems are those where sharia is not dominant, but plays a significant role in one or more areas of the nation's legal system. This is observed in majority of Muslim nations. == Map == [[File:Use of Sharia by country.svg|thumb|center|750px]] : {{legend|#179C86|Countries and members of the [[:en:Organisation of Islamic E.|title=An Overview of the Egyptian Legal System and Legal Research|url=http://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/Egypt1.htm|website=GlobaLex|publisher=New York University School of Law|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171123153543/http://www.nyulawglobal.org/Globalex/Egypt1.htm#|archive-date=2017-11-23|dead-url=no|df=}} however, the declaration of Sharia's primacy in Article 2 is a potential ground for unconstitutionality of any secular laws in Egyptian legal code.{{cite web|title=Egypt – The Judiciary, Civil Rights and the Rule of Law|url=http://countrystudies.us/egypt/115.htm|publisher=Library of Congress, USA|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304223532/http://countrystudies.us/egypt/115.htm#|archive-date=2016-03-04|dead-url=no|df=}} Sharia courts and qadis are run and licensed by the [[Ministry of Justice (Egypt)|Ministry of Justice]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7235357.stm |title=Incorporating Sharia into legal systems |publisher=BBC News |date=8 February 2008 |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130425031043/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7235357.stm# |archive-date=2013-04-25 |dead-url=no |df= }} The personal status law that regulates matters such as marriage, divorce and child custody is governed by sharia. In a family court, a woman’s testimony is worth half of a man’s testimony.{{cite web|title=Egypt Gender Equality Profile|url=http://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Egypt-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf|publisher=UNICEF|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181019172446/https://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Egypt-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf#|archive-date=2018-10-19|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Eritrea=== Sharia courts entertain cases dealing with marriage, inheritance and family of Muslims.{{cite web|title=Introduction To Eritrean Legal System And Research|url=http://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/Eritrea.htm|website=GlobaLex|publisher=New York University School of Law|accessdate=19 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130318023906/http://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/Eritrea.htm#|archive-date=2013-03-18|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Ethiopia=== Sharia courts have jurisdiction on cases regarding marriage, divorce, maintenance, guardianship of minors (only if both parties are Muslims). Also included are cases concerning waqfs, gifts, succession, or wills, provided that donor is a Muslim or deceased was a Muslim at time of death.{{cite web |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/Ethiopia.htm |title=Ethiopia |publisher=Law.emory.edu |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212024626/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/Ethiopia.htm# |archive-date=2013-02-12 |dead-url=no |df= }} ===Gabon=== It has a mixed legal system of French civil law and customary law. ===Gambia=== Article 7 of the [[Constitution of the Gambia|constitution]] identifies sharia as source of law in matters of personal status and inheritance among members of communities to which it applies.{{cite web |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/gambia.htm |title=Gambia |publisher=Law.emory.edu |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212052612/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/gambia.htm# |archive-date=2013-02-12 |dead-url=no |df= }} ===Ghana=== Ghana is a secular state. Any other laws inconsistent with the national constitution are deemed null and void. No religious laws are applied in civil or criminal cases .{{cite web |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/ghana.htm |title=Ghana |publisher=Law.emory.edu |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212041102/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/ghana.htm# |archive-date=2013-02-12 |dead-url=no |df= }} ===Guinea-Bissau=== It has a mixed legal system of civil law and customary law. ===Guinea=== It has a civil law system. ===Kenya=== Islamic law is applied by [[Kadhi courts|Kadhis' Courts]] where "all the parties profess the Muslim religion".{{cite web |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/kenya.htm |title=Kenya |publisher=Law.emory.edu |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116220016/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/kenya.htm# |archive-date=2013-01-16 |dead-url=no |df= }} Under article 170, section 5 of the [[Constitution of Kenya|constitution]], the jurisdiction of Kadhis’ court is limited to matters relating to "personal status, marriage, divorce or inheritance in proceedings in which all the parties profess the Muslim religion and submit to the jurisdiction of the Kadhi’s courts".{{cite web|title=The Constitution of Kenya|url=http://www.kenyaembassy.com/pdfs/The%20Constitution%20of%20Kenya.pdf|publisher=Embassy of the Republic of Kenya, Washington DC|accessdate=24 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121223095029/http://kenyaembassy.com/pdfs/The%20Constitution%20of%20Kenya.pdf#|archive-date=2012-12-23|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Libya=== Qaddafi merged civil and sharia courts in 1973. legal system of English common law and traditional law. ===Senegal=== The legal system of Senegal is based on French civil law.{{cite web|title=Customary and Islamic law in Senegal|url=http://www.legalbrief.co.za/article.php?story=20041217123824607|publisher=Legal Briefs (2004)|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006131459/http://www.legalbrief.co.za/article.php?story=20041217123824607#|archive-date=2014-10-06|dead-url=no|df=}} The 1972 Family Code (''Code de la famille''){{cite web|title=Code de la famille Sénégalais|url=http://www.jafbase.fr/docAfrique/Senegal/SenegalFam1.pdf|publisher=JaFBase|accessdate=3 October 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006080535/http://www.jafbase.fr/docAfrique/Senegal/SenegalFam1.pdf#|archive-date=2014-10-06|dead-url=no|df=}} is secular in nature.{{cite web|last1=Dièye|first1=Abdoulaye|title=Secularism in Senegal: Withstanding the Challenge of Local Realities|url=http://www.bcics.northwestern.edu/documents/workingpapers/ISITA_09-006_Dieye.pdf|publisher=Institute for the Study of Islamic Thought in Africa|accessdate=3 October 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605010921/http://www.bcics.northwestern.edu/documents/workingpapers/ISITA_09-006_Dieye.pdf#|archive-date=2010-06-05|dead-url=no|df=}} Islamic law is allowed by article 571 of the Family Code only in the case of [[intestate]] successions, and only if the person had demonstrated in life a wish that his succession would be regulated by Islamic law. Most succession cases are decided under this provision.{{cite book|author1=Mary Hallward-Driemeier|author2=Tazeen Hasan|title=Empowering Women: Legal Rights and Economic Opportunities in Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mv_isUM_vNgC&pg=PA55|date=4 October 2012|publisher=World Bank Publications|isbn=978-0821395349|page=55}} There has been growing political attempts to introduce more sharia regulations.{{cite web|last1=Dièye|first1=Abdoulaye|title=Secularism in Senegal: Withstanding the Challenge of Local Realities|url=http://www.bcics.northwestern.edu/documents/workingpapers/ISITA_09-006_Dieye.pdf|publisher=Institute for the Study of Islamic Thought in Africa|accessdate=3 October 2014|page=10|date=2009|quote=More recently a personal status code in accordance with the Sharia for Senegalese Muslims instead of the present Family Code was adopted and propagated by the Islamic Committee for the Reform of the Family Code in Senegal.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605010921/http://www.bcics.northwestern.edu/documents/workingpapers/ISITA_09-006_Dieye.pdf#|archive-date=2010-06-05|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Sierra Leone=== It has a common law system influenced by customary law. ===Somalia=== Sharia was adopted in 2009.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/03/10/idUSLA575453 |title=Somali cabinet votes to implement sharia law |publisher=Reuters |date=2009-03-10 |accessdate=2013-02-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023065759/http://www.reuters.com/article/2009/03/10/idUSLA575453# |archive-date=2012-10-23 |dead-url=no |df= }} Article 2 of Somali 2012 Constitution states no law can be enacted that is not compliant with the general principles and objectives of Sharia.{{cite web|title=UN officials welcome ‘historic’ approval of new constitution for Somalia|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=42603#.VBxVFSiRvP0|publisher=United Nations News Center (2012)|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170704172956/http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=42603#.VBxVFSiRvP0#.VBxVFSiRvP0|archive-date=2017-07-04|dead-url=no|df=}}{{cite web|title=Federal Republic of Somalia – Provisional Constitution |url=http://unpos.unmissions.org/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=RkJTOSpoMME= |publisher=United Nations (2012) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402122013/http://unpos.unmissions.org/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=RkJTOSpoMME%3D |archivedate=2 April 2015 }} Sharia currently influences all aspects of ''[[Xeer]]'' as well as Somalia's formal legal system.{{cite book|author1=Abdul Wahid Sh. Qalinle|editor1-last=Johansson Dahre|editor1-first=Ulf|title=Promoting Rule of Law in an Era of ‘Re-Islamization" in Somalia, Part IV in Predicaments in the Horn of Africa|publisher=Lund University Press|pages=331–42|url=http://www.sirclund.se/Dokument/10YearSIRCConf2012.pdf#page=331|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170615011416/http://www.sirclund.se/Dokument/10YearSIRCConf2012.pdf#page=331#page=331|archive-date=2017-06-15|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Sudan=== Sharia has been declared the chief source of all legislation in Sudan's 1968, 1973 and 1998 Constitutions.{{cite journal|last1=Clark Lombardi|title=Sharia – A or The Chief Source of Legislation|journal=International Law Review|date=2013|volume=28|issue=3|pages=751–53|url=http://www.auilr.org/pdf/28/28.3.3.pdf|publisher=American University|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140915030843/http://www.auilr.org/pdf/28/28.3.3.pdf#|archive-date=2014-09-15|dead-url=yes|df=}} In 2005, Sudan adopted an interim national constitution; it removed some references to Sharia, but included Sharia-derived criminal, civil and personal legal codes, as well as Sharia-mandated [[hudud]] punishments.{{cite book|last1=Koendgen|first1=Olaf|editor1-last=Otto|editor1-first=Jan|title=Sharia Incorporated|publisher=Leiden University Press|isbn=978-9087280574|pages=181–230}} The Criminal Act of 1991 prescribes punishments which include forty lashes for drinking alcohol, amputation of the right hand for theft of a certain value and stoning for adultery.{{cite book|author=Jan Michiel Otto|title=Sharia Incorporated: A Comparative Overview of the Legal Systems of Twelve Muslim Countries in Past and Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8ep7cX3ma0sC&pg=PA211|accessdate=18 February 2013|date=30 June 2010|publisher=Amsterdam University Press|isbn=978-9087280574|pages=211–212}}{{cite web|title=The Criminal Act 1991|url=http://www.pclrs.org/downloads/bills/Criminal%20Law/Criminal%20Act%201991%20English.pdf|publisher=PCLRS|accessdate=21 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526165737/http://www.pclrs.org/downloads/bills/Criminal%20Law/Criminal%20Act%201991%20English.pdf#|archive-date=2013-05-26|dead-url=no|df=}} However, there is no record of either any amputation or stoning ever having taken place in Sudan.[https://mic.com/articles/68431/women-around-the-world-are-being-stoned-to-death-do-you-know-the-facts#.B062VQHfy] ===Tanzania=== Islamic law is applicable to Muslims under the Judicature and Applications of Laws Act, empowering courts to apply Islamic law to matters of succession in communities that generally follow Islamic law in matters of personal status and inheritance. Unlike mainland Tanzania, [[Zanzibar]] retains Islamic courts.{{cite web|title=Guide to Tanzanian Legal System and Legal Research|url=http://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/tanzania.htm|website=GlobaLex|publisher=New York University School of Law|accessdate=19 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130202053957/http://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/Tanzania.htm#|archive-date=2013-02-02|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Togo=== It has a customary law system. ===Tunisia=== Tunisia has a long secular tradition with a legal system based on French civil law. The [[Code of Personal Status (Tunisia)|Law of Personal Status]], considered a reference in secular family law across the Arab world, bans polygamy and extrajudicial divorce. Sharia courts were abolished in 1956.{{cite web |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/tunisia.htm |title=Tunisia |publisher=Law.emory.edu |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130211234427/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/tunisia.htm# |archive-date=2013-02-11 |dead-url=no |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.llrx.com/features/tunisia.htm |title=Features – A Guide to the Tunisian Legal System |publisher=LLRX.com |date=15 September 2002 |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130303081950/http://www.llrx.com/features/tunisia.htm# |archive-date=2013-03-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Secular inheritance laws are indirectly based on Islamic jurisprudence, with religion never being mentioned in the Code of Personal Status; these laws accord to women half the share of property due to men.{{cite web|title=Will Tunisian Women Finally Inherit What They Deserve?|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2014/02/07/will-tunisian-women-finally-inherit-what-they-deserve/|publisher=Foreign Policy|accessdate=10 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150110045008/http://foreignpolicy.com/2014/02/07/will-tunisian-women-finally-inherit-what-they-deserve/#|archive-date=2015-01-10|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Uganda=== Article 129 (1) (d) of the [[Constitution of Uganda|constitution]] allows the parliament to establish by law "Qadhi’s courts for marriage, divorce, inheritance of property and guardianship".{{cite web|title=Constitution of Uganda|url=http://www.ec.or.ug/docs/Constitution.pdf|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6EcHrEWII?url=http://www.ec.or.ug/docs/Constitution.pdf#|archive-date=2013-02-22|dead-url=yes|df=}} ==Americas== ===Canada=== Sharia law is explicitly banned in [[Quebec]], [[Canada]], upheld by a unanimous vote against it in 2005 by the [[National Assembly of Quebec]],{{cite news|title=Quebec gives thumbs down to Shariah law|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/quebec-gives-thumbs-down-to-shariah-law-1.535601|accessdate=10 October 2017|work=CBC News|date=26 May 2005|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171009234834/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/quebec-gives-thumbs-down-to-shariah-law-1.535601#|archive-date=2017-10-09|dead-url=no|df=}} while the province of [[Ontario]] allows family law disputes to be arbitrated only under Ontario law.{{cite web|last1=Choski|first1=Bilal M.|title=Religious Arbitration in Ontario – Making the Case Based on the British Example of the Muslim Arbitration Tribunal|url=https://www.law.upenn.edu/live/files/970-choksi33upajintll7912012pdf|website=law.upenn.edu|accessdate=10 December 2015|date=14 March 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304072259/https://www.law.upenn.edu/live/files/970-choksi33upajintll7912012pdf#|archive-date=2016-03-04|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Guyana=== The country has a common law system. ===Suriname=== The country has a civil law system. ===United States=== In the United States, various states have outlawed sharia, or passed some form of ballot measure which "prohibits the states courts from considering foreign, international or religious law." {{as of|2014}} these include Alabama, Arizona, Kansas, Louisiana, North Carolina, South Dakota and Tennessee.{{cite web|last1=Farmer|first1=Liz|title=Alabama Joins Wave of States Banning Foreign Laws|url=http://www.governing.com/topics/elections/gov-alabama-foreign-law-courts-amendment.html|website=governing.com|accessdate=27 August 2015|date=4 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150910024007/http://www.governing.com/topics/elections/gov-alabama-foreign-law-courts-amendment.html#|archive-date=2015-09-10|dead-url=no|df=}} * Georgetown Journal of International Law, volume 36, issue 4; also see [http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/index2.html Sharia Law profile by Country] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116095035/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/index2.html# |date=2014-01-16 }}, Emory University (2011) ==Asia== ===Afghanistan=== Criminal law in Afghanistan continues to be governed in large part by Islamic law. The Criminal Law of September 1976 codifies sharia, and retains punishments such as the stoning to death of adulterers. However virtually all courts, including the [[Afghan Supreme Court|Supreme Court of Afghanistan]], rely on Islamic law directly.{{cite web|last=Lau|first=Martin|title=Afghanistan’s Legal System and its Compatibility with International Human Rights Standards|url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/pdfid/48a3f02c0.pdf|publisher=UNHCR|page=21|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170608225917/http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/pdfid/48a3f02c0.pdf#|archive-date=2017-06-08|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Azerbaijan=== The government is declared to be secular in the [[Constitution of Azerbaijan|constitution]].{{cite web |url=http://www.cfr.org/religion/islam-governing-under-sharia/p8034 |title=Islam: Governing Under Sharia |publisher=Council on Foreign Relations |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130203022058/http://www.cfr.org/religion/islam-governing-under-sharia/p8034# |archive-date=2013-02-03 |dead-url=no |df= }} ===Bahrain=== Article 2 of Bahrain's 2002 Constitution as originally adopted, as well as after February 2012 amendment, declares Islamic Sharia is a chief source of legislation. Four tiers of ordinary courts have jurisdiction over cases related to civil, administrative and criminal matters, with Court of Cassation the highest civil court in Bahrain; in all matters, the judges are required to resort to Sharia in case legislation is silent or unclear.{{cite web|title=Chapter III — Relevant Aspects of the Legal System and Description of the Enforcement Structures|url=http://www.govaction.bh/wps/themes/html/EgovBICI/en/pdfs/C3.pdf|publisher=Bahrain Government|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324203829/https://www.govaction.bh/wps/themes/html/EgovBICI/en/pdfs/C3.pdf#|archive-date=2016-03-24|dead-url=no|df=}} Sharia courts handle [[personal status]] laws.{{cite book|author=Gerhard Robbers|title=Encyclopedia of World Constitutions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M3A-xgf1yM4C&pg=PA73&dq|accessdate=20 August 2013|year=2006|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0816060788|page=73}}{{cite web|title=Bahrain|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/inline_images/Bahrain.pdf|publisher=Freedom House|page=4|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181002004344/https://freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/inline_images/Bahrain.pdf#|archive-date=2018-10-02|dead-url=no|df=}} A personal status law was codified in 2009 to regulate personal status matters. It applies only to Sunni Muslims; there is no codified personal status law for Shiites. In a Shari’a court a Muslim woman's testimony is worth half of that of a Muslim man.{{cite web|title=Bahrain Gender Equality Profile|url=http://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Bahrain-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf|publisher=UNICEF|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170620145410/https://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Bahrain-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf#|archive-date=2017-06-20|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Bangladesh=== Marriage, divorce, alimony and property inheritance are regulated by Sharia for Muslims.{{cite magazine |title=Women and property rights: Who owns Bangladesh? |url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/banyan/2013/08/women-and-property-rights |magazine=The Economist |type=Blog |date=21 August 2013 |accessdate=2 December 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207191111/http://www.economist.com/blogs/banyan/2013/08/women-and-property-rights# |archive-date=2013-12-07 |dead-url=no |df= }} The Muslim Personal Law (Shariat) Application Act, 1937 (XXVI of 1937) applies to Muslims in all matters relating to Family Affairs.{{cite web |url=http://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/bangladesh.htm |title=A Research Guide to the Legal System of the Peoples’ Republic of Bangladesh |website=GlobaLex |publisher=New York University School of Law |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130319151229/http://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/Bangladesh.htm# |archive-date=2013-03-19 |dead-url=no |df= }} Islamic family law is applied through the regular court system.{{cite web |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/bangladesh.htm |title=Bangladesh |publisher=Law.emory.edu |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140621041521/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/bangladesh.htm# |archive-date=2014-06-21 |dead-url=no |df= }} There are no limitations on interfaith marriages.{{cite book|author=Jonathan Fox|title=A World Survey of Religion and the State|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rE0NcgxNaKEC&pg=PA197|accessdate=18 February 2013|date=19 May 2008|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1139472593|page=197}} ===Brunei=== Sharia courts decide personal status cases or cases relating to religious offences.{{cite web |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/brunei.htm |title=Brunei |publisher=Law.emory.edu |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212080911/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/brunei.htm# |archive-date=2013-02-12 |dead-url=no |df= }} Sultan [[Hassanal Bolkiah]] declared in 2011 his wish to establish Islamic criminal law as soon as possible.{{cite web|title=Islamic Criminal Law in Brunei: Don't delay|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/10/11/islamic-criminal-law-brunei-dont-delay.html|publisher=The Jakarta Post|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305131808/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/10/11/islamic-criminal-law-brunei-dont-delay.html#|archive-date=2016-03-05|dead-url=no|df=}} A new penal code enacted in May 2014 will eventually prescribe sharia punishments, including the severing of limbs for property crimes and death by stoning for adultery and homosexuality.{{cite web|title=Sultan of Brunei imposes harsh Islamic criminal code|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/asia/la-fg-wn-brunei-sharia-law-20140501-story.html|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=7 May 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140506174624/http://www.latimes.com/world/asia/la-fg-wn-brunei-sharia-law-20140501-story.html#|archive-date=2014-05-06|dead-url=no|df=}} ===India=== The Muslim Personal Law (Shariat) Application Act 1937 directs the application of [[Muslim Personal Law]] to Muslims in a number of different areas, mainly related to family law.{{cite web |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/india.htm |title=India |publisher=Law.emory.edu |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116220209/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/india.htm# |archive-date=2013-01-16 |dead-url=no |df= }} ===Indonesia=== Aceh is the only part of Indonesia to apply Sharia in full. Islamic courts in Aceh had long handled cases of marriage, divorce and inheritance. After special autonomy legislation was passed in 2001, the reach of courts extend to criminal justice.{{Cite web |url=http://www.crisisgroup.org/~/media/Files/asia/south-east-asia/indonesia/117_islamic_law_and_criminal_justice_in_aceh.ashx# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2018-11-13 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304051340/http://www.crisisgroup.org/~/media/Files/asia/south-east-asia/indonesia/117_islamic_law_and_criminal_justice_in_aceh.ashx# |archive-date=2016-03-04 |dead-url=no |df= }} Offences such as being alone with an unrelated member of the opposite gender, gambling and breaking Islamic dress rules can be punished with a public caning.{{cite news|title=Aceh passes adultery stoning law|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8254631.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=21 February 2013|date=14 September 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130226082411/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8254631.stm#|archive-date=2013-02-26|dead-url=no|df=}} In 2014, the provincial government of [[Aceh]] extended sharia's reach, enacting and enforcing sharia to apply it to non-Muslims as well.[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/02/07/aceh-fully-enforces-sharia.html Aceh fully enforces sharia] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180307183758/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/02/07/aceh-fully-enforces-sharia.html# |date=2018-03-07 }} The Jakarta Post (7 February 2014)[https://www.economist.com/news/asia/21596577-politics-much-faith-behind-harder-line-laying-down-gods-law Laying down God's law] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170924183938/https://www.economist.com/news/asia/21596577-politics-much-faith-behind-harder-line-laying-down-gods-law# |date=2017-09-24 }} The Economist (15 February 2014). See [[Islamic criminal law in Aceh]]. In other parts of Indonesia, religious courts have jurisdiction over civil cases between Muslim spouses on matters concerning marriage, divorce, reconciliation, and alimony. The competence of religious courts is not exclusive, and parties can apply to District Courts for adjudication on basis of [[Roman Dutch law]] or local [[adat]].{{cite web |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/indonesia.htm |title=Indonesia |publisher=Law.emory.edu |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212080900/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/indonesia.htm# |archive-date=2013-02-12 |dead-url=no |df= }}{{update after|2014|8|22}} [[Suharto]]’s [[New Order (Indonesia)|New Order]] expanded the reach of Islamic law, first with the 1974 Marriage Act, which assigned jurisdiction over the marriage and divorce of Muslims to the Islamic courts ({{lang-id|peradilan agama}}), and with the 1989 Religious Judicature Act, which elevated Islamic courts by making them a parallel legal system, equal to state courts and gave them jurisdiction over inheritance (''wasiyyah''), gifts (''hibah'') and religious endowments. Muslim litigants could originally choose whether to have inheritance questions decided by the Islamic courts or by the civil courts, but a 2006 amendment eliminated this possibility; the same amendment gave Islamic courts new jurisdiction over property disputes, including financial and economic matters. Muslims seeking a divorce must also file their claim in Islamic courts. The Compilation of Islamic Law 1991 ({{lang-id|Kompilasi Hukum Islam}}) regulates marriage, inheritance, and charitable trusts ([[wakaf]]). Islamic law falls outside the jurisdiction of the [[Constitutional Court of Indonesia|Constitutional Court]].{{cite web|author1=Mark E. Cammack|author2=R. Michael Feener|title=The Islamic Legal System In Indonesia|url=http://digital.law.washington.edu/dspace-law/bitstream/handle/1773.1/1091/21PRPLJ013.pdf|accessdate=22 August 2014|pages=17–32|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170701133616/http://digital.law.washington.edu/dspace-law/bitstream/handle/1773.1/1091/21PRPLJ013.pdf#|archive-date=2017-07-01|dead-url=no|df=}} Since 2006, a number of [[Districts of Indonesia|districts]] have issued local ordinances based on sharia.{{cite web|title=Indonesia|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2012/indonesia|work=Freedom in the World 2012|publisher=Freedom House|accessdate=23 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130131081103/http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2012/indonesia#|archive-date=2013-01-31|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Iran=== Article 167 of the [[Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran|constitution]] states that all judicial rulings must be based upon "authoritative Islamic sources and authentic fatwa".{{cite book|author=Jonathan Fox|title=A World Survey of Religion and the State|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rE0NcgxNaKEC&pg=PA231|accessdate=19 February 2013|date=19 May 2008|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1139472593|page=231}} Book 2 of the Islamic Penal Code of Iran is entirely devoted to hudud punishments.{{Cite web |url=http://rc.majlis.ir/fa/law/show/845048# |title=قانون مجازات اسلامی |access-date=2018-11-13 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180815105408/http://rc.majlis.ir/fa/law/show/845048# |archive-date=2018-08-15 |dead-url=no |df= }} Iranian application of sharia has been seen by scholars as highly flexible and directly contradicting traditional interpretations of the sharia.{{cite book|last=Abrahamian|first=Ervand|title=A History of Modern Iran|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|location=Cambridge, UK; New York|year=2008|isbn=978-0521528917|page=190|quote=They allowed women to study abroad on state scholarships. They even passed bills directly contradicting traditional interpretations of the sharia. They eliminated all distinctions between men and women, between Muslims and non-Muslims, in accepting witnesses in court and awarding monetary compensations for damages. They increased the marriageable age for girls to fifteen (from thirteen). They reopened the judiciary to women. They gave them equal rights in divorce courts and permitted them to have custody rights over children under the age of seven. Never before in the Middle East had a freely elected parliament so blatantly challenged basic tenets of the sharia. What is more, they ratified the UN Convention on Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women – the USA has still refused to ratify this highly egalitarian convention. The liberal cause was further bolstered when Ayatollah Youssef Sanai, one of Khomeini’s favorite disciples, came out in full support of women’s rights. He ruled that the law should not differentiate between the sexes, and that women should have the right to become presidents, chief judges, and even Supreme Leaders.}} ===Iraq=== Article 1 of Civil Code identifies Islamic law as a main source of legislation.{{cite web |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/iraq.htm |title=Iraq, Republic of |publisher=Law.emory.edu |date=16 March 1983 |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116220220/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/iraq.htm# |archive-date=2013-01-16 |dead-url=no |df= }} The 1958 Code, made polygamy extremely difficult, granted child custody to the mother in case of divorce, prohibited repudiation and marriage under the age of 16. In 1995, Iraq introduced Sharia punishment for certain types of criminal offenses.{{cite book|author=Jonathan Fox|title=A World Survey of Religion and the State|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rE0NcgxNaKEC&pg=PA238|accessdate=18 February 2013|date=19 May 2008|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1139472593|page=238}} Iraq's legal system is based on French civil law as well as Sunni and Jafari (Shi’ite) interpretations of Sharia.{{cite web |url=http://www.islamopediaonline.org/country-profile/iraq/islam-and-legal-system/religion-law-and-iraq%E2%80%99s-personal-status-code |title=Religion, Law, and Iraq’s Personal Status Code |publisher=[[Islamopedia Online]] |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130530225211/http://www.islamopediaonline.org/country-profile/iraq/islam-and-legal-system/religion-law-and-iraq%E2%80%99s-personal-status-code# |archive-date=2013-05-30 |dead-url=no |df= }} Article 41 of the [[Constitution of Iraq|constitution]] allows for personal status matters (such as marriage, divorce and inheritance) to be governed by the rules of each religious group. The article has not yet been put into effect, and a unified personal status law remains in place that builds on the 1959 personal status code.{{cite web|title=Iraq Gender Equality Profile|url=http://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Iraq-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf|publisher=UNICEF|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170620180303/https://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Iraq-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf#|archive-date=2017-06-20|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Israel=== Islamic law is one of the sources of legislation for Muslim citizens. Islamic law is binding on personal law issues for Muslim citizens.{{cite news|title=Josh Goodman: What Sharia Law in Democracies Tells Us About Islam|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/josh-goodman/post_965_b_744095.html|publisher=HuffPost Religion|date=29 September 2010|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305024952/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/josh-goodman/post_965_b_744095.html#|archive-date=2016-03-05|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Jordan=== Jordan has [[Sharia]] [[courts]] and civil courts. Sharia courts have jurisdiction over personal status laws, cases concerning [[Diyya|Diya]] (blood money in cases of crime where both parties are Muslims, or one is and both the Muslim and non-Muslim consent to Sharia court's jurisdiction), and matters pertaining to Islamic Waqfs.{{cite web|url=http://www.law.yale.edu/rcw/rcw/jurisdictions/asw/jordan/jordan_const_eng.pdf|title=Jordan, Hashemite Kingdom of|publisher=Law.yale.edu|page=21|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150616070132/http://www.law.yale.edu/rcw/rcw/jurisdictions/asw/jordan/jordan_const_eng.pdf#|archive-date=2015-06-16|dead-url=yes|df=}} The Family Law in force is the Personal Status Law of 1976, which is based on Islamic law .{{cite web|title=Women In Personal Status Laws: Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, Palestine, Syria|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/fileadmin/MULTIMEDIA/HQ/SHS/pdf/Women_in_Personal_Status_Laws.pdf|work=SHS Papers in Women’s Studies/ Gender Research, No. 4|publisher=UNESCO|date=July 2005|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171010052503/http://www.unesco.org/new/fileadmin/MULTIMEDIA/HQ/SHS/pdf/Women_in_Personal_Status_Laws.pdf#|archive-date=2017-10-10|dead-url=no|df=}} In Sharia courts, the testimony of two women is equal to that of one man.{{cite web|title=Jordan Gender Equality Profile|url=http://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Jordan-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf|publisher=UNICEF|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170620190921/https://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Jordan-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf#|archive-date=2017-06-20|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Kazakhstan=== Islamic law was in force up until early 1920.{{cite web |url=http://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/kazakhstan1.htm |title=UPDATE: Laws of the Republic of Kazakhstan |website=GlobaLex |publisher=New York University School of Law |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531140000/http://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/kazakhstan1.htm# |archive-date=2013-05-31 |dead-url=no |df= }} The 1995 [[Constitution of Kazakhstan|constitution]] is not based on sharia.{{cite book|author=Paul Brummell|title=Kazakhstan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CH3PY_LSOlAC&pg=PA21|accessdate=18 February 2013|date=1 March 2012|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|isbn=978-1841623696|page=21}} Legislation|journal=American University International Law Review|date=2013|volume=28|issue=3|pages=733–74|url=http://www.auilr.org/pdf/28/28.3.3.pdf|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140915030843/http://www.auilr.org/pdf/28/28.3.3.pdf#|archive-date=2014-09-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite According to the [[United Nations]], Kuwait's legal system is a mix of [[British common law]], [[French civil law]], [[Egyptian Civil Code|Egyptian civil law]] and Islamic law.{{cite web|url=http://unpan1.un.org/intradoc/groups/public/documents/un/unpan023178.pdf?q=kuwait|title=State of Kuwait, Public Administration Profile|page=7|publisher=[[United |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/kuwait.htm |title=Kuwait, State of |publisher=Law.emory.edu |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116215642/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/kuwait.htm# |archive-date=2013-01-16 |dead-url=no |df= }} Before a family court the testimony of a woman is Kuwait blocks internet content prohibited by Sharia.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8hSbPrABnbsC&pg=PA261&dq|title=Routledge Handbook of Media Law|pages=262–64|author1=Monroe E. Price |author2=Stefaan Verhulst |author3=Libby Morgan |year=2013|isbn=978-1135109004}} ===Kyrgyzstan=== It has a civil law system. However converting a Muslim is a crime.{{cite web|url=http://www.refworld.org/docid/48d5cbf72.html|title=Kyrgyz Republic – Religious Laws|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170924224740/http://www.refworld.org/docid/48d5cbf72.html#|archive-date=2017-09-24|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Lebanon=== Lebanon's legal system is based on a combination of [[Civil law (legal system)|Civil Law]], Islamic law and [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] laws.{{cite web|title=The Lebanese Constitution promulgated on May 23, 1926, with its Amendments|url=http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/details.jsp?id=6675|publisher=[[World Intellectual Property Organization]]|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170924184247/http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/details.jsp?id=6675#|archive-date=2017-09-24|dead-url=no|df=}} There are eighteen official religions in Lebanon, each with its own family law and religious courts. For the application of personal status laws, there are three separate sections: Sunni, Shia and non-Muslim. The Law of 16 July 1962 declares that Islamic law governs personal status laws of Muslims, with Sunni and Ja'afari Shia jurisdiction of Islamic law. ===Malaysia=== Schedule 9 of Malaysian constitution recognizes Islamic law as a state subject; in other words, the states of Malaysia have the power to enact and enforce sharia. 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710211518/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125102803820651875#|archive-date=2015-07-10|dead-url=no|df=}} and adultery.{{cite web|title=Malaysia begins Several sharia crimes, such as ''khalwat'' (close proximity of unmarried man and woman) are punishable only in Sharia courts of Malaysia. Publishing an Islamic book that is different from official Malaysian version, without permission, is a crime in some states. Other sharia-based criminal laws were enacted with "Syariah Criminal Offences (Federal Territory) Act of 1997". Muslims are bound by Sharia on personal matters, while members of other faiths follow civil law. Muslims are required to follow Islamic law in family, property and religious matters.{{cite book|author=Jonathan Fox|title=A World Survey of Religion and the State|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rE0NcgxNaKEC&pg=PA198|accessdate=18 February 2013|date=19 May 2008|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1139472593|page=198}} In 1988 the [[Constitution of Malaysia|constitution]] was amended to state that civil courts cannot hear matters that fall within the jurisdiction of Sharia courts.{{cite news |last=Pak |first=Jennifer |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-14630851 |title=Malaysia's parallel judicial systems come up against legal challenges |publisher=BBC News |date=5 September 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130202083826/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-14630851# |archive-date=2013-02-02 |dead-url=no |df= }} ===Maldives=== Article 15 of the Act Number 1/81 (Penal Code) allows for [[hudud]] punishments.{{cite web|title=Maldives Penal Code|url=http://www.agoffice.gov.mv/pdf/sublawe/PC1.pdf|accessdate=19 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130607090225/http://www.agoffice.gov.mv/pdf/sublawe/PC1.pdf#|archive-date=2013-06-07|dead-url=no|df=}} Article 156 of the [[Constitution of the Maldives|constitution]] states that law includes the norms and provisions of sharia.{{cite web |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/maldives.htm |title=Maldives |publisher=Law.emory.edu |date=16 March 1983 |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130211221153/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/maldives.htm# |archive-date=2013-02-11 |dead-url=no |df= }} ===Myanmar=== In [[Myanmar]], sharia has been applied for personal status issues since colonial times, under section 13 of Burma Law Act, 1898. Court precedents also decided that [[Waqf]] matters are to be decided under Islamic law. The 1952 Myanmar Muslim Dissolution of Marriage Act states that a Muslim woman has the right to divorce her husband with appropriate cause. Matters relating to sharia family law are decided by civil courts.{{cite web |last1=Aung |first1=Marlar Than |title=Current Legal Framework of Islamic Family Law in Myanmar |url=http://www.burmalibrary.org/docs21/Marlar_Than_Aung-Current_Legal_Framework_of_Islamic_Family_Law_in_Myanmar.pdf |accessdate=13 November 2018 |dead-url=no |df= }} ===Oman=== Islamic Sharia is the basis for legislation in Oman per Article 2 of its Constitution, and promulgated as Sultani Decree 101/1996.{{cite web|last1=Mechantaf|first1=Khalil|title=The Legal System and Research in the Sultanate of Oman|url=http://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/Oman.htm|website=GlobaLex|publisher=New York University School (Family) Law issued by Royal Decree 97/32 codified provisions of Sharia.{{cite web |url=http://www.mofa.gov.om/mofanew/index.asp?id=18 |title=Sultanate of Oman |publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080505064242/http://www.mofa.gov.om/mofanew/index.asp?id=18# |archive-date=2008-05-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Sharia Court Departments within the civil court system are responsible for personal status matters.{{cite web |url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2012/oman |title=Oman |publisher=Freedom House |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025073322/http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2012/oman# |archive-date=2012-10-25 |dead-url=no |df= }} A Profile|url=http://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Oman-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf|publisher=UNICEF|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170620174153/https://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Oman-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf#|archive-date=2017-06-20|dead-url=no|df=}} Oman's criminal law is based on a combination of Sharia and English common law.{{cite book|author=Graeme R. Newman|title=Crime and Punishment around the World [4 volumes]: [Four Volumes]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2uK6bR9byVIC&pg=PA336|date=19 October 2010|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0313351341|pages=336–37}} Omani commercial law is largely based on Sharia; Article 5 of its Law of Commerce defaults to primacy of Sharia in cases of confusion, silence or conflict. ===Pakistan=== Until 1978 Islamic law was largely restricted to personal status issues. [[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|Zia ul Haq]] introduced Sharia courts and made far reaching changes in the criminal justice system.{{cite web |url=http://www.islamopediaonline.org/country-profile/pakistan/islam-and-legal-system |title=Islam and the Legal System |publisher=[[Islamopedia Online]] |date= |accessdate=2013-02-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104170613/http://www.islamopediaonline.org/country-profile/pakistan/islam-and-legal-system# |archive-date=2012-11-04 |dead-url=no |df= }} Articles 203a to 203j of the [[Constitution of Pakistan|constitution]] establish a sharia court with the power to judge any law or government actions to be against Islam, and to review court cases for adherence to Islamic law. The penal code includes elements of sharia.{{cite book|author=Jonathan Fox|title=A World Survey of Religion and the State|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rE0NcgxNaKEC&pg=PA200|accessdate=2013-02-18|date=2008-05-19|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1139472593|page=200}} Under article 5, section 2 of the [[Hudood Ordinance|Ordinance No. VII of 1979]], whoever is guilty of [[zina]], "if he or she is a [[muhsan]], be stoned to death at a public place; or if he or she is not a muhsan, be punished, at a public place, with whipping numbering one hundred stripes".{{cite web|title=The Offence of Zina (Enforcement of Hudood) Ordinance (VII of 1979)|url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/pdfid/4db999952.pdf|publisher=UNHCR|accessdate=21 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170608213615/http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/pdfid/4db999952.pdf#|archive-date=2017-06-08|dead-url=no|df=}} Under a [[Women's Protection Bill|2006 law]], rape cases can be heard under civil as well as Islamic law.{{cite news|title=Pakistan votes to amend rape laws|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/6148590.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=21 February 2013|date=2006-11-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114173029/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/6148590.stm#|archive-date=2012-11-14|dead-url=no|df=}} ===Philippines=== There are sharia trial and circuit trial courts in [[Mindanao]], which is home to the country's significant [[Islam in the Philippines|Filipino Muslim]] minority.{{cite book|author=Oxford Business Group|title=The Report: The Philippines 2010|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k10wHwlXvgMC&pg=PA14|accessdate=19 February 2013|publisher=Oxford Business Group|isbn=978-1907065118|page=14}} Sharia District Courts (SDCs) and Sharia Circuit Courts (SCCs) were created in 1977 through Presidential Decree 1083, which is also known as the Code of Muslim Personal Laws.{{cite web|title=A primer on the Philippine Sharia courts|url=http://www.muslimmindanao.ph/shari%27a/code_muslim.pdf|publisher=Asian Institute of Journalism and Communication|accessdate=19 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130820052012/http://www.muslimmindanao.ph/shari%27a/code_muslim.pdf#|archive-date=2013-08-20|dead-url=no|df=}} Islamic law only applies to civil cases involving all Muslims nationwide. Cases are handled in the [[Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao]] and a couple of Mindanao provinces that are not part of ARMM by both sharia district and circuit courts, organised into five sharia districts. Outside these areas, sharia-related cases are processed in civil courts under a session from the five sharia districts.[http://www.chanrobles.com/presidentialdecreeno1083.htm Code of Muslim Personal Laws of the Philippines] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181111000009/http://www.chanrobles.com/presidentialdecreeno1083.htm# |date=2018-11-11 }}. All other cases, including criminal ones, are dealt with by local civil courts.{{cite web |title=Analysis: Mindanao’s uncertain road to peace |url=http://www.irinnews.org/report/96627/analysis-mindanao-s-uncertain-road-to-peace |publisher=IRIN News |accessdate=14 January 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150107224011/http://www.irinnews.org/report/96627/analysis-mindanao-s-uncertain-road-to-peace# |archive-date=2015-01-07 |dead-url=no |df= }} ===Qatar=== [[Sharia]] is the main source of Qatari legislation according to Qatar's Constitution.{{cite web|title=The Permanent Constitution of the State of Qatar|url=http://www.almeezan.qa/LawArticles.aspx?LawArticleID=25754&LawId=2284&language=en|publisher=Government of Qatar|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006075128/http://www.almeezan.qa/LawArticles.aspx?LawArticleID=25754&LawId=2284&language=en#|archive-date=2014-10-06|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|title=Constitution of Qatar|url=http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/details.jsp?id=9626|quote=According to Article 1: Qatar is an independent Arab country. Islam is its religion and Islamic law is the main source of its legislation.|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006153437/http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/details.jsp?id=9626#|archive-date=2014-10-06|dead-url=no|df=}} Islamic law is applied to laws pertaining to [[family law]], [[inheritance]], and several [[criminal law|criminal acts]] (including adultery, robbery and murder). In some cases in Sharia-based [[family court]]s, a female's testimony is worth half a man's and in some cases a female witness is not accepted at all.{{cite web|title=Qatar Gender Equality Profile|url=http://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Qatar-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf|publisher=UNICEF|access-date=2018-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140629121154/http://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Qatar-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf#|archive-date=2014-06-29|dead-url=no|df=}} [[Flogging]] is used in Qatar as a punishment for alcohol consumption or illicit sexual relations. Article 88 of Qatar's criminal code declares the punishment for adultery is [[flagellation|100 lashes]]. Adultery is punishable by death when a Muslim woman and a non-Muslim man are involved. Court has jurisdiction over cases related to marriage, divorce, betrothal, nullity of marriage, judicial separation, division of property on divorce, payment of dowry, maintenance, and [[Mut'ah|muta]].{{cite web |url=http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/singapore.htm |title=Singapore |publisher=Law.emory.edu |accessdate=18 February 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212052632/http://www.law.emory.edu/ifl/legal/singapore.htm# |archive-date=2013-02-12 |dead-url=no |df= }} ===Sri Lanka=== Private matters of Muslims are governed by Muslim Law, including marriage, divorce custody and maintenance.
